Author: Responsible-Pain-620

Comment: A few years ago I (30sF) went on a date with a guy who was 31 and said he was giving himself ten years to decide if be wanted kids. I said that’s nice that he has that option, and that women don’t really have that luxury. He said “my mom was 41 when she had me”. I told him that was great but that for many women, it doesn’t work out that way, and that egg quantity and quality decline drastically over time. He said “well they can just do IVF!” and I mentioned that it’s really costly, hard on your body, and is not guaranteed to result in pregnancy, either. I also pointed out that as women age, there’s a higher risk of complications for both mother and baby.  After that conversation, I was curious about what men’s impression of female fertility was, so I asked a couple of male friends in their 30s what they thought/knew. They pretty much had the same outlook as the first guy.  Plenty of men who eventually want kids are out here acting like they’re Robert DeNiro and can wait until they’re 80 to become a dad, seemingly not even aware that sperm quality decreases over time and that advanced paternal age can lead to complications, as well. Women definitely have a much more limited timeline than men, but men shouldn’t be taking their fertility for granted either.  So, it seems like if anyone could benefit from classes that would help inform people with the goal of increasing the birth rate, maybe they should…teach men some things. Many of them seem to be in no hurry to have children.  I want to have children more than anything. I have tried to find a suitable partner, to no avail. Even if/when I find a partner, I’m unsure whether having a baby will financially possible. And FWIW, I also tried to have my eggs frozen, but it would’ve cost me $16k. The $5k they want to offer is laughable…is that supposed to go toward raising the child? Because with many insurance plans, that won’t even cover the cost of a baby being born. In summary, no, women don’t need a “menstrual class”.

Comment: For sure, no disagreement. I just mean that the concept of paying people to have children is a good one. The last time the Republicans were in power Marco Rubio fought to increase the child tax credit. Which was also a solid decision.  The problem is that conservatives don't really think about how a one time (or once a year) infusion of money isn't really solving anything.  Free pre-K, free 3-K, enhanced maternity/paternity leave, improved healthcare, etc. will all go much further towards helping people feel financially secure.   I'm just saying I agree with the general concept of supporting families financially. They just tend to be so far removed from what families actually need that they think tossing a couple thousand dollar bills here and there will solve it. And it's a good start, but they are allergic to what is, in reality, the necessary followups.

Author: steelhips

Comment: > Minimum wage is supposed to be the bottom level, an entry point.  Minimum wage is supposed to be the bare minimum a person needs to support a family.   Don't believe me? Let's hear it from the man himself who championed, fought for, and eventually signed, minimum wage into law.   From Franklin D. Roosevelt himself:  >“It seems to me to be equally plain that no business which depends for existence on paying less than living wages to its workers has any right to continue in this country. By "business" I mean the whole of commerce as well as the whole of industry; by workers I mean all workers, the white collar class as well as the men in overalls; and by living wages I mean more than a bare subsistence level-I mean the wages of decent living.”  Oh, and if you think that doesn't mean what I said it means, here's another quote from him about it.   >Throughout industry, the change from starvation wages and starvation employment to living wages and sustained employment can, in large part, be made by an industrial covenant to which all employers shall subscribe. It is greatly to their interest to do this because decent living, widely spread among our people, eventually means the opening up to industry of the richest market which the world has known.  Still not convinced he meant a living wage? Here's another quote.  >On this idea, the first part of the Act proposes to our industry a great spontaneous cooperation to put millions of men back in their regular jobs this summer. The idea is simply for employers to hire more men to do the existing work by reducing the work-hours of each man's week and at the same time paying a living wage for the shorter week.   And before you bring up how it'd hurt companies for minimum wage to be a living wage; he addressed that argument too.   >No employer and no group of less than all employers in a single trade could do this alone and continue to live in business competition. But if all employers in each trade now band themselves faithfully in these modern guilds--without exception-and agree to act together and at once, none will be hurt and millions of workers, so long deprived of the right to earn their bread in the sweat of their labor, can raise their heads again.  But it'll raise prices you're going to cry. Don't worry, he had an answer for that too.  >I am fully aware that wage increases will eventually raise costs, but I ask that managements give first consideration to the improvement of operating figures by greatly increased sales to be expected from the rising purchasing power of the public. That is good economics and good business.  Edited to add more quotes.
